Description: Conical bowl of Nile silt pottery with a flat base, flaring sides and a slightly everted rim; coated with red slip, burnished and decorated on the interior in white paint with three large cross-hatched triangles and a circle in the centre filled with two chevrons from which emerge three different vegetal motifs. The exterior is unpainted.
Curator's comments: Similar to White cross-lined ware C35 of Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). The continuation of life in a land of abundance was the ambition for the afterlife. This aspiration is reinforced by the white painting on this bowl in the style characteristic of the Naqada I period. It is suggested that the central circle represents a pond of water, or perhaps a desert oasis, out of which lush vegetation grows, set within the desert hills represented by the cross-hatched triangles. Published: A. Roveri and F. Tiradritte [eds.], Kemet: Alle Sorgenti del Tempo, Ravenna 1998, p.167 [75]. G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 39.
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Sir Robert Ludwig Mond
